content.text: Define acceleration
The combined mass of the aeroplane, its passengers and its fuel on take-off is \(1.1 \times 10^{5} \text{kg}\)
Calculate the average resultant force on the aeroplane between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 35 \text{s}\)
The force provided by the engines of the aeroplane is constant
Give **one** possible explanation for the change in acceleration of the aeroplane between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 35 \text{s}\)
On Fig. 1.2, sketch a graph to show how the acceleration of the aircraft varies between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 35 \text{s}\)
(i) Calculate the average acceleration of the aeroplane between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 35 \text{s}\)
acceleration =   .........
An aeroplane accelerates along a horizontal runway before take-off
The aeroplane accelerates for 35 s. The speed of the aeroplane when it takes off is \(72 \text{m/s}\)
Fig. 1.1 shows how the speed of the aeroplane varies between time \(t = 0\) and \(t = 35 \text{s}\)
Calculate the change in momentum of the ball while it is in contact with the racket
change in momentum =   .........
State an equation which defines impulse in terms of force and time
Calculate the time that the racket is in contact with the ball
Calculate the difference between the values of the kinetic energy of the ball before and after the impact with the racket
difference in kinetic energy =   .........
Fig. 2.1 shows a tennis ball approaching a tennis racket

The tennis ball hits the racket at a speed of \(52 \text{m / s}\). The average force on the ball during the time that it is in contact with the racket is \(350 \text{N}\). The speed of the ball after it leaves the racket is \(26 \text{m / s}\) in the opposite direction to the initial speed of the ball. The mass of the ball is \(58 \text{g}\)
Complete the sentences to describe the energy transfers which take place when the gates are opened
Use words from the list
**tidal bay** **kinetic** **gates** **gravitational potential**
**open sea** **turbines** **water**
rotating .................................................. . This energy is used in the generator to produce
electrical power
State one advantage and one disadvantage of tidal power as an energy resource
advantage
disadvantage
State the main source of energy for tidal energy
Fig. 3.1 shows the cross-section of a barrage built across a tidal bay. The barrage is part of a tidal power station

The gates are raised to be open when the tide comes in. The gates are lowered to close when it is high tide. Fig. 3.1 shows the water levels in the open sea and the tidal bay when it is low tide. The gates are raised and water flows through the turbine
State the physical property which varies with temperature in a liquid-in-glass thermometer
Thermometer Y has a bulb that contains twice the volume of liquid compared to thermometer X
State and explain how the sensitivity of thermometer Y compares with the sensitivity of thermometer X
statement
explanation
State and explain **one** change that can be made to the design of thermometer X to increase its range
statement
explanation
Fig. 4.1 shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer labelled thermometer X
A liquid-in-glass thermometer cannot measure a temperature of 1300 °C
State a physical property which varies with temperature in a thermometer which can measure a temperature of 1300 °C
Three identical dishes, A, B and C, contain an equal volume of water
Dish A is outside in sunlight and experiences no wind during the day. Dish B is outside in sunlight and experiences a strong wind during the day. Dish C is in a dark room
Water evaporates from each dish. After 12 hours, a student measures the volume of water in each dish. Dish C contains the largest volume of water and dish B contains the smallest volume of water
Explain, in terms of particles, why the three dishes have different volumes of water
Define specific latent heat of vaporisation
Fig. 5.1 shows an insulating beaker, crushed ice, an immersion heater and a thermometer
The initial temperature of the ice is \(-60^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The immersion heater is switched on and the temperature is recorded at equal intervals of time
Fig. 5.2 shows the temperature–time graph
Describe what occurs in each of the sections A, B, C and D
A
B
C
D
the direction of travel of the reflected wave
three successive reflected wave crests
On Fig. 6.1, draw:
Fig. 6.2 shows an identical wave approaching a barrier with a gap of \(1.3 \text{cm}\)
On Fig. 6.2, draw **three** successive wave crests after they pass through the gap in the barrier
The frequency of the wave is 4.0 Hz
Calculate the speed of the wave
Fig. 6.1 shows wave crests and the direction of travel for a water wave approaching a barrier in a large ripple tank
The wavelength of the wave is \(1.6 \text{cm}\)
State what is meant by total internal reflection
The refractive index of the liquid is 1.5
Calculate the largest value of \(x\) for which total internal reflection can occur
The speed of light in air is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the speed of light in the liquid
Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of light from a light source in a tank containing a liquid
The ray of light strikes the surface of the liquid at an angle x
Describe and explain how the apparatus shown in Fig. 8.1 can be used to charge the metal plate
Fig. 8.2 shows an electric circuit
On Fig. 8.2, draw an arrow to show the direction of flow of electrons and explain how you determined the direction
Fig. 8.1 shows apparatus used to charge a metal plate by induction
Calculate the time period (time for one complete cycle) of the a.c. supply
sketch a graph to show how the p.d. across the resistor varies with time for two cycles
label the p.d. axis with the value of p.d. at the peak
label the time axis with two values of time
The peak potential difference (p.d.) across the resistor is 340 V
On Fig. 9.2:
Fig. 9.1 shows a circuit with an alternating current (a.c.) supply, a resistor and a diode
The frequency of the power supply is \(50 \text{Hz}\)

A cloud chamber can be used to detect \(\alpha\) (alpha)-particles and \(\beta\) (beta)-particles. Alcohol in the cloud chamber exists as a vapour and condenses on ions produced in the air. This forms visible tracks
Fig. 10.1 shows the tracks when a source of \(\alpha\)-particles and \(\beta\)-particles is present in the cloud chamber
Some of the tracks are short and thick. Other tracks are longer and thinner
State and explain which tracks are produced by \(\alpha\)-particles and which tracks are produced by \(\beta\)-particles
\(\alpha\) -particles
\(\beta\) -particles
Describe what is meant by an isotope
Write down the nuclide equation for the decay of this isotope of sodium to magnesium
This isotope of sodium has a half-life of 15 hours. The isotope of magnesium is stable and does not undergo radioactive decay
Suggest why these properties of the isotope of sodium and the isotope of magnesium make this isotope of sodium suitable to detect leaks from water pipes

A radioactive isotope of sodium (Na) is used to detect leaks from water pipes. A nucleus of this isotope of sodium contains 11 protons and 13 neutrons. This nucleus decays by emitting a \(\beta\)-particle to form a nucleus of magnesium (Mg)
Fig. 11.1 shows a solenoid connected to a battery
On Fig. 11.1, draw the pattern of the magnetic field inside and around the solenoid. Indicate the direction of the magnetic field with an arrow

Electrical power is transmitted at a voltage of \(400\mathrm{kV}.\) A transformer reduces the voltage to \(33\mathrm{kV}\) for use by heavy industry in large factories. The number of turns on the primary coil of the transformer is 11 000
Calculate the number of turns on the secondary coil of the transformer
number of turns =   .........
